title: Devonport Strikers suffer back - to - back losses in NPL Tasmania | The Advocate
body_text:
For the first time in six years, the Devonport Strikers have recorded back-to-back losses in the NPL Tasmania competition.

The reigning champion's southern road trip was well and truly spoiled by ladder leaders Glenorchy - going down 4-0 during the round 13 clash.
It was a disappointing result for coach Tom Ballantyne, who felt that the group "just didn't get it right".
"We've had a few players out through illness and injury, and potentially we should have done some things slightly different," Ballantyne said.
"But we wanted to try and put our best foot forward, and potentially play some players who weren't 100 per cent.
"We just didn't get it right and that's pretty brutal but it's that black and white. We didn't get it right from early on to late in the game."
Despite the result, Ballantyne remained optimistic that the fourth-placed could once again return to the top of the table with seven games remaining in the season.
"It's on us; we've got six points to make up to get on top," he said.
"There's still one third of the season left and the team that can put seven wins together wins the league.
"We've got very strong characters in the group and some very good football players. It's just a matter of getting it right."
STRENGTH-TO-STRENGTH
While it was a tough road trip for the men's side, the Strikers' Women's Super League side notched up their 10th win of the season.
A double to Lucy Foote and Madeline Payne led the visitors to a 6-0 victory against the Knights on Saturday, July 13.
Ballantyne had nothing but praise for the side's efforts and even said parts of the game were "really joyful to watch".
"They've really taken on what we're trying to do with them and they just seem to be having fun now," he said.
Whitney Knight and Danielle Capel also hit the scoreboard.
GOALS GALORE
A six-goal haul from Jordan Payne has helped the club's NPL Tasmania under 21 side to a hefty victory against Glenorchy.
The visitors proved difficult to stop in front of goals in the 12-0 win. Overeager Miles Barnard also hit the scoreboard on five occasions.
The win helps to cement the side's place at the top-of-the-table.
